text.tspan: When mitering offset polygons, offset distances (ie the
distance between the old and new vertices where edges
join) can be almost infinite when the angle between adjacent
edges is very small. To address this problem, an arbitrary
offset limit is needed (usually expressed as a multiple of the
edge offset distance) so that when a mitered join would
otherwise exceed this limit, edges are 'square' joined instead.
Consequently, given an arbitrary offset limit, we need to know
how narrow an angle can be (or conversely how large the
change in angle can be) before 'squaring' is needed.
Given: Î´ represents the edge offset distance; ÃŸ the change in
angle between adjacent edges; and Î» Ã— Î´ the maximum
distance allowed between old and new vertices ...
How large can ÃŸ be before 'squaring' be required?
Let: Î» Ã— Î´ = length(ab); and Ã˜ = Ï€ - ÃŸ,
And squaring both sides ... 1 â€“ cos(Ã˜) = 2 / Î»Â²
and given cos(Ï€ â€“ ÃŸ) = â€“cos(ÃŸ) ** ...
Example: if the miter limit (Î») = 2 (ie 2 Ã— Î´), then
So when ÃŸ > 120 deg. (or Ã˜ < 60 deg.), offseting will
exceed the offset distance of 2 Ã— Î´Â and the join will
